editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Sùndry times acted by the children of Paul's.
By Thomas Decker, and John Webster.
Imprinted at London by G. eld. 1607.

div.head: Actus primus.
div.stage: Enter Luke greenshield with Fetherstone booted.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Art sure old Maybery inns here tonight ,

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: 'Tis certain the honest knave chamberlain that hath been my informer, my bawd, ever since I knew Ware assures me of it, and more being a Londoner though altogether unacquainted, I have requested his company at supper.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Excellent occasion: how we shall carry ourselves in this business is only to be thought upon.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Be that my undertaking: if I do not take a full revenge of his wives puritanical coyness.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Suppose it she should be chaste,

sp.speaker: Greenshield
sp.p: O hang her: this art of seeming honest makes many of our young sons and heirs in the city, look so like our prentices, — chamberlain.

sp.speaker: Chamberlain
sp.p: Hear sir. Enter Chamberlaine.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: This honest knave is called innocence, is't not a good name for a chamberlain? he dwelled at Dunstable not long since, and hath brought me and the two butcher's daughters there to interview twenty times and not so little I protest: how chance you left Dunstable sirrah?

sp.speaker: Chamberlain
sp.p: Faith sir the town drooped ever since the peace in Ireland, your captains were wont to take their leaves of their London polecats, (Their wenches I mean sir) at Dunstable: the next morning when they had broke their fast together the wenches brought them to quickly ith' hole, and so the one for London the other for Westchester, your only road now sir is York York sir.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: True, but yet it comes scant of the prophecy; Lincoln was, London is, and York shall be.

sp.speaker: Chamberlain
sp.p: Yes sir, 'tis fulfilled, York shall be, that is, it shall be York still, surely it was the meaning of the prophet: will you have some crayfish, and a spitchcock.

div.stage: Enter Maybery with Bellamont.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: And a fat trout.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: You shall sir; the Londoners you wot of:

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Most kindly welcome — I beseech you hold our boldness excused sir.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: Sir it is the health of travellers, to enjoy good company: will you walk.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Whether travail you I beseech you.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: To London sir we came from Sturbridge.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I tell you gentlemen I have observed very much with being at Sturbridge; it hath afforded me mirth beyond the length of five Latin comedies; here should you meet a Norfolk yeoman ful-but; with his head able to overturn you; and his pretty wife that followed him, ready to excuse the ignorant hardness of her husband's forehead, in the goose markt number of freshmen; stuck here and there, with a graduate: like cloves with great heads in a gammon of bacon: here two gentlemen making a marriage between their heirs over a woolpack; there a minister's wife that could speak false latin very lispingly; here two in one corner of a shop: Londoners selling their wares, and other gentlemen courting their wives; where they take up petticoats you should find scholars and townsmen's wives crowding together while their husbands wear in another market busy amongst the oxen; 'twas like a camp for in other countries so many punks do not follow an army. I could make an excellent description of it in a comedy: but whether are you travailing gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Feth
sp.p: Faith sir we purposed a dangerous voyage, but upon better consideration we altered our course.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: May we without offence partake the ground of it.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: 'Tis altogether trivial insooth: but to pass away the time till supper, I'll deliver it to you, with protestation before hand, I seek not to publish every gentlewoman's dishonour, only by the passage of my discourse to have you censure the state of our quarrel.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Forth sir.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Frequenting the company of many merchants' wives in the city, my heart by chance leapt into mine eye to affect the fairest but with all the falsest creature that ever affection stooped to.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Of what rank was she I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Upon your promise of secrecy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You shall close it up like treasure of your own, and yourself shall keep the key of it,

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: She was and by report still is wife to a most grave and well reputed citizen.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: And entertained your love.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: As meadows do April: the violence as it seemed of her affection — but alas it proved her dissembling, would at my coming and departing bedew her eyes with love drops; oh she could the art of woman most feelingly.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Most feelingly.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I should not have liked that feelingly had she been my wife, give us some sack hear and in faith — we are all friends; and in private — what was her husband's name ▪ — I'll give you a carouse by and by.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: O you shall pardon me his name, it seems you are a citizen, it would be discourse enough for you upon the exchange this fortnight should I tell his name.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your modesty in this wife's commendation; on sir.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: In the passage of our loves, (Amongst other favours of greater value) she bestowed upon me this ring which she protested was her husband's gift.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: The poesy, the poesy — oh my heart, that ring good in faith:

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Not many nights coming to her and being familiar with her.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Kissing and so forth.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I sir.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: And talking to her feelingly.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Pox on't, I lay with her.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Good in faith you are of a good complexion.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Lying with her as I say: and rising somewhat early from her in the morning, I lost this ring in her bed.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: In my wife's bed.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: How do you sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Nothing: lets have a fire chamberlain; I think my boots have taken water I have such a shudering: ith' bed you say;

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Right sir, in mistress Maybery's sheets.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Was her name Maybery.

sp.speaker: Green
sp.p: Beshrew my tongue for blabbing, I presume upon your secrecy.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O God sir, but where did you find your losing;

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Where I found her falseness: with this gentleman; who by his own confession partaking the like enjoyment; found this ring the same morning on her pillow, and shamed not in my sight to wear it.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p:
What did she talk feelingly to him too; I warrant her husband was forth a town all this while,
and he poor man travailed with hard eggs in's pocket, to save the charge of a bait, whilst she was at home with her plovers, Turkey, chickens; do you know that Maibery.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: No more than by name.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: He's a wondrous honest man; let's be merry; will not your mistress gentlemen, you are tenants in common I take it.

sp.speaker: Feth Gree.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Will not your mistress make much of her husband when he comes home as if no such legerdemain had been acted.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Yes she hath reason for't, for in some countries, where men and women have good travailing stomachs, they begin with porridge; then they fall to capon or so-forth: but if capon come short of filling their bellies, to their porridge again, 'tis their only course, so for our women in England.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: This wit taking of long journeys: kindred that comes in o'er the hatch, and sailing to Westminster makes a number of cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fie what an idle quarrel is this, was this her ring?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Her ring sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: A pretty idle toy, would you would take money for't,

sp.speaker: Feth. Green.
sp.p: Money sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: The more I look on't, the more I like it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Troth 'tis of no great value, and considering the loss, and finding of this ring made breach into your friendship, gentlemen, with this trifle purchase his love, I can tell you he keeps a good table.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: What my mistress gift?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Faith you are a merry old gentleman; I'll give you my part in't.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Troth and mine, with your promise to conceal it from her husband.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Doth he know of it yet?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: He shall never then I protest ● look you this ring doth fit me passing well.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: I am glad we have fitted you.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: This walking is wholesome, I was a cold even now, now I sweat for't.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Shall's walk into the garden Luke. Gentlemen we'll down and hasten supper.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Look you, we must be better acquainted that's all.

div.stage: Exeunt Green. and Feth.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Most willingly; excellent, he's heat to the proof, let's withdraw, and give him leave to rave a little.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Chamberlain, give us a clean towel.

div.stage: Enter Chamberlaine.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How now man?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I am foolish old Maybery, and yet I can be wise Maybery too; I'll to London presently, begone sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How, how?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Nay, nay, god's precious you do mistake me master Bellamont; I am not distempered, for to know a man's wife is a whore, is to be resolved of it, and to be resolved of it, is to make no question of it, and when a case is out of question; what was I saying?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why look you, what a distraction are you fallen into?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: If a man be divorced, do you see, divorced forma juris, whether may he have an action or no, 'gainst those that make horns at him?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O madness! that the frailty of a woman should make a wise man thus idle! yet I protest to my understanding, this report seems as far from truth, as you from patience.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Then am I a fool, yet I can be wise and I list too: what says my wedding ring?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Indeed that breeds some suspicion: for the rest most gross and open, for two men, both to love your wife, both to enjoy her bed, and to meet you as if by miracle, and not knowing you, upon no occasion in the world, to thrust upon you a discourse of a quarrel, with circumstance so dishonest, that not any gentleman but of the country blushing, would have published. I and to name you: do you know them?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Faith now I remember, I have seen them walk muffled by my shop.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Like enough; pray God they do not borrow money of ●● twixt Ware and London: come strive to blow over these clouds.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Not a cloud, you shall have clean moonshine, they have good smooth looks the fellows.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As jet, they will take up I warrant you, where they may be trusted; will you be merry?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Wondrous merry; let's have some sack to drown this cuckold, down with him: wondrous merry: one word and no more; I am but a foolish tradesman, and yet I'll be a wise tradesman. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter D●ll lead between Leuer-poole, and Chartley, after them Philip arrested.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Arrest me? at whose suit? Tom Chartley, Dick Leverpoole, stay, I'm arrested.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Arrested?

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.p: Gentlemen break not the head of the peace; it's to no purpose, for he's in the laws clutches, you see he's fanged.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Uds life, do you stand with your naked weapons in your hand, and do nothing with 'em? put one of 'em into my fingers, I'll tickle the pimple-nosed varlets.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Hold Doll, thrust not a weapon upon a mad woman, officers step back into the tavern, you might ha' ta'en me ith' street, and not ith' tavern entry, you cannibals.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: We did it for your credit sir.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: How much is the debt? Drawer, some wine.

div.stage: Enter drawer.

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.p: Four score pound: can you send for bail sir? or what will you do? we cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: You cannot, you pasty-footed rascals, you will stay one day in hell.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Four score pounds draws deep; farewell Doll, come sergeants, I'll step to mine uncle not far off, hereby in pudding lane, and he shall bail me: if not, Chartly you shall find me playing at span-counter, and so farewell. Send me some tobacco.

sp.speaker: 1. Servant
sp.p: Have an eye to his hands.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant
sp.p: Have an eye to his legs. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I'm as melancholy now?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Villainous spiteful luck, I'll hold my life some of these saucy drawers betrayed him.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: We sir! no by gad sir, we scorn to have a Judas in our company.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: No, no, he was dogged in, this is the end of all dying.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: This is the end of all whores, to fall into the hands of knaves. Drawer, tie my shoe pry thee: the new knot as thou seest this: Philip is a good honest gentleman, I love him because he'll spend, but when I saw him on his father's hobby, and a brace of punks following him in a coach, I told him he would run out, hast done boy?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Yes forsooth: by my troth you have a dainty leg.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: How now goodman rogue.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Nay sweet mistress Doll.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Doll! you reprobate! out you bawd for seven years by the custom of the city.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Good mistress Dorothy; the pox take me, if I touched your leg but to a good intent.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Prate you: the rotten toothed rascal, will for six pence fetch any whore to his master's customers: and is every one that swims in a taffety gown lettuce for your lips? uds life, this is rare, that gentlewomen and drawers, must suck at one spigot: do you laugh you unseasonable puckfist? do you grin?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Away drawer: hold pry thee good rogue, hold my sweet doll, a pox a this swaggering.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Pox a your guts, your kidneys; mew: hang ye, rook: I'm as melancholy now as Fleetstreet in a long vacation.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Melancholy? come we'll ha' some mulled sack.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: When begins the term?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Why? hast any suits to be tried at Westminster?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: My suits you base ruffian have been tried at Westminster already: so soon as ever the term begins, I'll change my lodging, it stands out a the way; I'll lie about Charing-cross, for if there be any stirrings, there we shall have 'em: or if some Dutchman would come from the states! o! these Flemings pay soundly for what they take.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: If thou'lt have a lodging westward doll, I'll fit thee.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p:
At Tyburn will you not? A lodging of your providing? to be called a lieutenant's, or a captain's wench! o! I scorn to be one of your Low-country commodities, I; is this body made to be maintained with provant and dead
pay? no: the mercer must be paid, and satin gown 〈…〉 be ta'en up.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: And gallon pots must be tumbled down.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Stay: I have had a plot a breeding in my brains — are all the quest-houses broken up?

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Yes, long since: what then?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: What then? marry then is the wind come about, and for those poor wenches that before Christmas fled westward with bag and baggage, come now sailing alongst the lee shore with a northerly wind ▪ and we that had warrants to lie without the liberties, come now dropping into the freedom by owl-light sneakingly.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But doll, what's the plot thou spak'st off?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Marry this: gentlemen, and tobacco-stinckers, and such like are still buzzing where sweet meats are (Like flies) but they make any flesh stink that they blow upon: I will leave those fellows therefore in the hands of their laundresses: silver is the King's stamp, man God's stamp, and a woman is man's stamp, we are not currant till we pass from one man to another.

sp.speaker: Both:
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: I will therefore take a fair house in the city: no matter though it be a tavern that has blown up his master: it shall be in trade still, for I know divers taverns ith' town, that have but a wall between them and a hothouse. It shall then be given out, that I'm a gentlewoman of such a birth, such a wealth, have had such a breeding, and so forth, and of such a carriage, and such qualities, and so forth: to set it off the better, old Jack Hornet shall take upon him to be my father.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Excellent, with a chain about his neck and so forth.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: For that, saint Martin's and we will talk: I know we shall have gudgeons bite presently: if they do boys, you shall live like knights fellows; as occasion serves, you shall wear liveries and wait, but when gulls are my windfalls, you shall be gentlemen, and keep them company: seek out Jack Hornet incontinently.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: We will; come charely, we'll play our parts I warrant.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Do so: —
The world's a stage, from which strange shapes we borrow:
Today we are honest, and rank knaves tomorrow. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Maybery, Bellamont, and a prentice.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Where is your mistress, villain? when went she abroad?

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: Abroad sir, why as soon as she was up sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Up sir, down sir, so sir: master Bellamont, I will tell you a strange secret in nature, this boy is my wife's bawd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O fie sir, fie, the boy he does not look like a bawd, he has no double chin.

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: No sir, nor my breath does not stink, I smell not of garlic or aquavitae: I use not to be drunk with sack and sugar: I swear not God dam me, if I know where the party is, when 'tis a lie and I do know: I was never carted (But in harvest) never whipped but at school: never had the grincoms: never sold one maidenhead ten several times, first to an Englishman, then to a Welshman, then to a Dutchman, then to a pocky Frenchman, I hope sir I am no bawd then.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Thou art a baboon, and holdest me with tricks, while my wife grafts grafts, away, trudge, run ▪ search her out by land, and by water.

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: Well sir, the land I'll ferret, and after that I'll search her by water, for it may be she's gone to Brainford. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mayb.
sp.p: Inquire at one of mine ants.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: One of your ants are you mad?

sp.speaker: Mayb.
sp.p: Yea, as many of the twelve companies are, troubled, troubled.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I'll chide you: go too, I'll chide you soundly.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O master Bellamont!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O master Maybery! before your servant to dance a Lancashire hornpipe: it shows worse to me, then dancing does to a deaf man that sees not the fiddles: 'sfoot you talk like a player.

sp.speaker: Mayb.
sp.p: If a player talk like a madman, or a fool, or an ass, and knows not what he talks, then I'm one: you are a poet master Bellamont, I will bestow a piece of plate upon you to bring my wife upon the stage, would not her humour please gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: I think it would: yours would make gentlemen as fat as fools: I would give two pieces of plate, to have you stand by me, when I were to write a jealous man's part: jealous men are either knaves or coxcombs, be you neither: you wear yellow hose without cause.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Without cause, when my mare bears double: without cause?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And without wit.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: When two virginal jacks skip up, as the key of my instrument goes down!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: They are two wicked elders.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: When my wife's ring does smoke for't.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your wife's ring may deceive you.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O master Bellamont! had it not been my wife had made me a cuckold, it should never have grieved me.

sp.speaker: Bael,
sp.p: You wrong her upon my soul.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: No, she wrongs me upon her body.

div.stage: Enter a servingman.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Now blue-bottle? what fl●tter you for sea-pie?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Not to catch fish sir, my young master, your son master Philip is taken prisoner.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: By the dunkirks.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Worse: by catchpoles: he's encountered.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Shall I never see that prodigal come home.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Yes sir, if you'll fetch him out, you may kill a calf for him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: For how much lies he?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: The debt is four score pound, marry he charged me to tell you it was four score and ten, so that he lies only for the odd ten pound.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: His child's part shall now be paid, this money shall be his last, and this vexation the last of mine: if you had such a son master Maiberie.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: To such a wife, 'twere an excellent couple.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Release him, and release me of much sorrow, I will buy a son no more: go redeem him. Enter prentice and Maybery's wife.

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: Here's the party sir.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: Hence, and lock fast the doors, now is my prize.

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: If she beat you not at your own weapon, would her buckler were cleft in two pieces. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I will not have you handle her too roughly.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: No, I will like a justice of peace, grow to the point: are not you a whore: never start: thou art a clothworker, and hast turned me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: How sir, into what sir, have I turned you?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Into a civil suit: into a sober beast: a land-rat, a cuckold: thou art a common bedfellow, art not? art not?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Sir this language, to me is strange, I understand it not.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O! you study the French now.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Good sir, lend me patience.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I made a salad of that herb: dost see these flesh-hooks, I could tear out those false eyes, those cat's eyes, that can see in the night: punk I could.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hear her answer for herself.

sp.speaker: Vvif.
sp.l: Good master Bellomont,
Let him not do me violence: dear sir,
Should any but yourself shoot out these names,
I would put off all female modesty,
To be revenged on him.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Know'st thou this ring? there has been old running at the ring since I went.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Yes sir, this ring is mine, he was a villain,
That stole it from my hand: he was a villain:
That put it into yours.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.l: They were no villains,
When they stood stoutly for me: took your part:
And stead of colours fought under my sheets.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: They lay with thee: I mean plain dealing.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: With me! if ever I had thought unclean,
In detestation of your nuptial pillow:
Let sulphur drop from heaven, and nail my body
Dead to this earth: that slave, that damned fury
(Whose whips are in your tongue to torture me)
Casting an eye unlawful on my cheek,
Haunted your threshold daily, and threw forth
All tempting baits which lust and credulous youth,
Apply to our frail sex: but those being weak
The second siege he laid was in sweet words.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: And then the breach was made.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay, nay, hear all.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: At last he takes me sitting at your door,
seizes my palm, and by the charm of oaths
(Back to restore it straight) he won my hand,
To crown his finger with that hoop of gold.
I did demand it, but he mad with rage
And with desires unbridled, fled and vowed,
That ring should me undo: and now belike
His spells have wrought on you. But I beseech you,
To dare him to my face, and in mean time
Deny me bedroom ▪ drive me from your board,
Disgrace me in the habit of your slave,
Lodge me in some uncomfortable vault
Where neither sun nor moon may touch my sight,
Till of this slander I my soul acquit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Guiltless upon my soul.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.l: Troth so think I.
I now draw in your bow, as I before
Supposed they drew in mine: my stream of jealousy,
Ebbs back again, and I that like a horse
Ran blindfold in a mill (All in one circle)
Yet thought I had gone foreright, now spy my error:
Villains you have abused me, and I vow
Sharp vengeance on your heads: drive in your tears
I take your word you're honest, which good men,
Very good men will scarce do to their wives.
I will bring home these serpents and allow them,
The heat of mine own bosom: wife I charge you
Set out your haviours towards them in such colours,
As if you had been their whore, I'll have it so,
I'll candy o'er my words, and sleek my brow,
Entreat 'em that they would not point at me,
Nor mock my horns, with this arm I'll embrace 'em
And with this — go too.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O we shall have murder — you kill my heart.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.l: No: I will shed no blood,
But I will be revenged, they that do wrong
Teach others way to right: I'll fetch my blow
Fair and afar off and as fencers useEnter Philip and servant
Though at the foot I strike, the head I'll bruise.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll join with you: let's walk: o! here's my son.
Welcome ashore sir: from whence come you pray.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: From the house of prayer and fasting — the counter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Art not, thou ashamed to be seen come out of a prison.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.p: No gods my judge, but I was ashamed to go into prison.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I am told sir, that you spend your credit and your coin upon a light woman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I ha' seen light gold sir, pass away amongst mercers.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And that you have laid thirty or forty pounds upon her back in taffety gowns, and silk petticoats.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: None but tailors will say so, I ne'er laid any thing upon her back: I confess I took up a petticoat and a razed forepart for her, but who has to do with that?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Marry that has everybody master Philip.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Leave her company, or leave me, for she's a woman of an ill name.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Her name is Dorothy sir, I hope that's no ill name.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What is she? what wilt thou do with her?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: 'Sblood sir what does he with her?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Dost mean to marry her? of what birth is she? what are her comings in, what does she live upon?

sp.speaker: Phillip.
sp.p: Rents sir, rends, she lives upon her rends, and I can have her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You can.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nay father, if destiny dog me I must have her: you have often told me the nine muses are all women, and you deal with them, may not I the better be allowed one than you so many? look you sir, the Northern man loves white-meats, the Southery man salads, the Essex man a calf, the Kentishman a wagtail, the Lancashire man an egg-pie, the Welshman leeks and cheese, and your Londoners raw mutton, so father good-bye, I was born in London.

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p:
Stay, look you sir, as he that lives upon salads without mutton, feeds like an ox, (For he eats
grass you know) yet rises as hungry as an ass, and as he that makes a dinner of leeks will have lean cheeks, so, thou foolish Londoner, if nothing but raw mutton can diet thee, look to live like a fool and a slave, and to die like a beggar and a knave, come master Maiberie, farewell boy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Farewell father Snot — sir if I have her, I'll spend more in mustard and vinegar in a year, than both you in beef.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: More saucy knave thou. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus 2. Scaena. 1.
div.stage: Enter Hornet, Doll, Leverpoole and Chartly like serving-men.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Am I like a fiddler's base viol (New set up,) in a good case boys? is't neat, is it terse! am I handsome? ha ▪

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Admirable, excellent.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: An under sheriff cannot cover a knave more cunningly.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: 'Sfoot if he should come before a churchwarden, he would make him pew-fellow with a lord's steward at least.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: If I had but a staff in my hand, fools would think I were one of Simon and Jude's gentlemen ushers, and that my apparel were hired: they say three tailors go to the making up of a man, but I'm sure I had four tailors and a half went to the making of me thus: this suit though it ha' been canvased well, yet 'tis no lawsuit, for 'twas dispatched sooner than a posset on a wedding night.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Why I tell thee Jack Hornet, if the devil and all the brokers in long lane had rifled their wardrobe, they would ha' been damned before they had fitted thee thus.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Punk, I shall be a simple father for you: how does my chain show now I walk.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: If thou wert hung in chains, thou couldst not show better.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: But how fit our blue-coats on our backs.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: As they do upon bankrupt retainers backs at saint George's feast in London: but at Westminster, it makes 'em scorn the badge of their occupation: there the bragging velure-canioned hobby-horses, prance up and down as if some a the tilters had ridden 'em.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Nay 'sfoot, if they be bankrupts, 'tis like some have ridden
'em: and thereupon the citizen's proverb rises, when he says; he trusts to a broken staff.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Hornet, now you play my father, take heed you be not out of your part, and shame your adopted daughter.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: I will look gravely doll, (Do you see boys) like the foreman of a jury: and speak wisely like a Latin schoolmaster, and be surly and dogged, and proud like the keeper of a prison.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: You must lie horribly, when you talk of your lands.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: No shopkeeper shall out lie me, nay, no fencer: when I hem boys, you shall duck: when I cough and spit gobbets doll.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: The pox shall be in your lungs Hornet.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: No doll, these with their high shoes shall tread me out.

sp.speaker: Doll,
sp.p: All the lessons that I ha' pricked out for 'em, is when the weathercock of my body turns towards them, to stand bare.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: And not to be saucy as serving-men are.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Come, come, we are no such creatures as you take us for.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: If we have but good draughts in my peterboat, fresh salmon you sweet villains shall be no meat with us.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: 'Sfoot nothing moves my choler, but that my chain is copper: but 'tis no matter, better men than old Jack Hornet have rode up Holborn, with as bad a thing about their necks as this: your ●ight whistler indeed hangs himself in saint Martin's, and not in Cheapside.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Peace, somebody rings: run both, whilst he has the the rope in's hand if it be a prize, hale him, if a man a war, blow him up, or hang him out at the main yards end.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: But what ghost, (Hold up my fine girl) what ghosts haunts thy house?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Oh! why divers: I have a clothier's factor or two; a grocer that would feign pepper me, a Welsh captain that lays hard siege, a Dutch merchant, that would spend all that he's able to make ith' low countries, but to take measure of my holland sheets when I lie in 'em: I hear trampling: 'tis my Flemish hoy.

div.stage: Enter Leverpoole, Chartly and Hans van Belch.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p:
Dar is vor you, and warrant you: e'en, twea, dry, vier, and
vive skilling, drinks Skellum vysie freeze: nempt, dats v drink gelt.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Till our crowns crack again master Hans van Belch.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: How is't met you, how is't bro? ur●lick?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Ick vare well God danke you: nay I'm an apt scholar and can take.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Datt is good, dott is good: ick can néet stay long: for ick heben skip come now upon de vater: oh mine schoomen uro, we sall dance lanteera, teera, and sing ick brinks to you min here, van: — what man is dat uro.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Nay pray sir on.

sp.speaker: Hans
sp.p: Wat honds foot is dat Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: 'Tis my father.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Gotts sacrament! your vader! why seyghen you niet so to me! mine heart 'tis mine all great desire, to call you mine vader ta for ick love dis schonen uro your dochterkin.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Sir you are welcome in the way of honesty.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Ick bedanck you: ick heb so ghe founden vader.

sp.speaker: Harn.
sp.p: What's your name I pray.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Mun nom been Hans van Belch.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Hans van Belch!

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yau, yau, 'tis so, 'tis so, de drunken man is alteet remember me.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Do you play the merchant, son Belch.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yau vader: ick heb de skip swim now upon de vater if you endouty, go up in de little skip dat go so, and been pulled up to Wapping, ick sal bear you on my back, and hang you about min neck into min groet skip.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: He says doll, he would have thee to Wapping and hang thee.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: No father I understand him, but master Hans, I would not be seen hanging about any man's neck, to be counted his jewel, for any gold.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Is your father living master Hans.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yau, yau, min vader heb schonen husen in Ausburgh groet mine hair is mine vaders brother, mine vader heb land, and been full of see, dat is beasts, cattle

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: He's lousy belike.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Min vader been be grotest fooker in all Ausbrough.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: The greatest what?

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Fooker he says.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Out upon him.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Yaw yaw, fooker is en groet min here he's en elderman vane city, gets sacrament, what is de clock? Ick met stay. A watch.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Call his watch before you, if you can.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Here's a pretty thing: do these wheels spin up the hours! what's o'clock .

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Acht: yaw 'tis acht.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: We can hear neither clock, nor Jack going, we dwell in such a place that I fear I shall never find the way to church, because the bells hang so far; such a watch as this, would make me go down with the lamb, and be up with the lark.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Seghen you so, dor it to.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: O fie: I do but jest, for in truth I could never abide a watch.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Gotts sacrament, ick niet heb it any more.

div.stage: Exeunt Leuer-poole and Chartly.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: another peal! good father launch out this Hollander.

sp.speaker: Horn.
sp.p: Come master belch, I will bring you to the waterside, perhaps to Wapping, and there I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Ick bedanck you vader. Exit.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: They say whores and bawds go by clocks, but what a Manasses is this to buy twelve hours so dear, and then be begged out of 'em so easily? he'll be out at heels shortly sure for he's out about the clocks already: oh foolish young man how dost thou spend thy time?

div.stage: Enter Leuer-poole first, then Allom and Chartly.

sp.speaker: Leur.
sp.p: Your grocer.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Nay 'sfoot, then I'll change my tune: I may cause such leaden-heeled rascals; out of my sight: a knife, a knife I say: oh master Allom, if you love a woman, draw out your knife and undo me, undo me.

sp.speaker: Allo.
sp.p: Sweet mistress Dorothy, what should you do with a knife, it● ill meddling with edge tools, what's the matter masters! knife God bless us.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: 'Sfoot what tricks at noddy are these.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: O I shall burst, if I cut not my lace: I'm so vexed! my father he's rid to court: one was about a matter of a 1000. pound weight; and one of his men like a rogue as he is is rid another way for rends, I looked to have had him up yesterday, and up today, and yet he shows not his head; s●●e he's run away, or robbed and run through; and here was a scrivener but even now, to put my father in mind of a bond, that will be forfeit this night if the money be not paid master Allom. Such cross fortune!

sp.speaker: Allo.
sp.p: How much is the bond?

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: O rare little villain.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: My father could take up, upon the bareness of his word five hundred pound: and five toe.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: What is the debt?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: But he scorns to be — and I scorn to be —

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: Prithee sweet mistress Dorothy vex not, how much is it?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Alas master Allom, 'tis but poor fifty pound.

sp.speaker: Allo.
sp.p: If that be all, you shall upon your word take up so much with me: another time I'll ●un as far in your books.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Sir, I know not how to repay this kindness: but when my father —

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Tush, tush, 'tis not worth the talking: just 50 pound? when is it to be paid.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Between one and two.

sp.speaker: L●ue
sp.p: That's we three.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: Let one of your men go along, and I'll send your fifty pound!

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: You so bind me sir, — go sirrah: master Allom, I ha' some quinces brought from our house ith' country to preserve, when shall we have any good sugar come over? the wars in Barbary make sugar at such an excessive rate; you pay sweetly now I warrant, sir do you not.

sp.speaker: Al
sp.p: You shall have a whole chest of sugar if you please.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Nay by my faith four or five loves will be enough, and I'll pay you at my first child master Allom.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: Content i'faith, your man shall bring all under one, I'll borrow a kiss of you at parting.

div.stage: Enter captain Jenkins.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: You shall sir, I borrow more of you. Ex. Allo. and Leu.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: Save you captain.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Welcome good captain Jenkins.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: What is he a barber surgeon, that dressed your lips so.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: A barber ● he's may tailor; I bid him measure how high, he would make the standing collar of my new taffety gown before, and he as tailors will be saucy and liquorish, laid me o'er the lips.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Uds blood I'll lay him cross upon his coxcomb next day.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: You know 'tis not for a gentlewoman to stand with a knave, for a small matter, and so I would not strive with him, only to be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: If I take master pricklouse ramping so high again, by this iron (Which is none a god's angel) I'll make him know how to kiss your blind cheeks sooner: mistress Dorothy Hornet, I would not have you be a hornet, to lick at cowsherds, but to sting such shreds of rascality: will you sing a tailor shall have me my joy?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Captain, I'll be led by you in any thing! A tailor! foh.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Of what stature or size have you a stomach to have your husband now?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Of the meanest stature captain, not a size longer than yourself , nor shorter.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By god, 'tis well said: all your best captain in the Low-countries are as taller as I: but why of my pitch mistress Dol?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Because your smallest arrows fly farthest; ah you little hard-favoured villain, but sweet villain, I love thee because thou'lt draw a my side, hang the rogue that will not fight for a woman.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Uds blood, and hang him for urse than a rogue that will slash and cut for an oman, if she be a whore.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Prithee good captain Jenkins, teach me to speak some Welsh, methinks a Welshman's tongue is the neatest tongue! —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: As any tongue in the urld, unless cramacrees, that's urse.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: How do you say, I love you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Mi cara whee, en hellon.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Mi cara whee, en hellhound.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Hell ▪ hound, o mondu, my cara whee, en hellon.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: O, my cara whee en hellon.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Oh! and you went to writing school twenty score year in Wales, by Sesu, you cannot have better utterance, for Welsh.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Come tit me, come that me, come throw a kiss at me, how is that?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By gad I know not, what your tit mees and that mees are, but me uatha — 'sblood I know what kisses be, as well as I know a Welsh hook, if you will go down with Shropshire carriers ▪ you shall have Welsh enough in your pellies forty weeks.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Say captain that I should follow your colours into your country how should I fare there?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Fare? by Sesu, oh there is the most abominable seere! and wider silver pots to drink in, and softer beds to lie upon and do our necessary pusines, and fairer houses and parks, and holes for coneys, and more money, besides toasted sees and buttermilk in North-wales diggon: besides, harps, and Welsh freeze, and goats, and cow-heels, and metheglin, ouh, it may be set in the chronicles, will you march thither?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Not with your Shropshire carriers, captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Will you go with captain Jenkin and see his cousin Maddoc upon Jenkin there, and I'll run hedlongs by and by, and batter away money for a new coach to jolt you in.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Bestow your coach upon me, and two young white mares, and you shall see how I'll ride.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Will you? by all the leeks that are worn on saint Davies day I will buy not only a coach, with four wheels, but also a white mare and a stone horse too, because they shall traw you, very lustily, as if the devil were in their arses. Exit.how now, more tailors —Meets Phillip.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How sir; tailors.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: O good captain, 'tis my cousin.

div.stage: Enter Leverpoole at another door.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Is he, I will cozen you then sir too, one day.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I hope sir then to cozen you too.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By gad I hobe so, farewell Sidanien. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Here's both money, and sugar.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: O sweet villain, set it up. Exit, and enter presently.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, what tame swaggerer was this I met doll.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: A captain, a captain: but hast 'scaped the dunkirks honest Philip? Philip rials are not more welcome: did thy father pay the sho●?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He paid that shot, and then shot pistolets into my pockets: hark wench: chinck chink, makes the punk wanton and the bawd to wink. Capers.

sp.speaker: Chart.
sp.p: O rare music.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Heavenly consort, better than old moons.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But why? why Dol, go these two like beadles in blue? ha?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: There's a moral in that: flay off your skins, you precious cannibals: oh that the Welsh captain were here again, and a drum with him, I could march now, ran, tan, tan, tara, ran, tan, tan, sirrah Philip has thy father any plate in's house.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Enough to set up a goldsmith's shop.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Canst not borrow some of it? we shall have guests tomorrow or next day and I would serve the hungry ragamuffins in plate, though 'twere none of mine own.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I shall hardly borrow it of him but I could get one of mine ants, to beat the bush for me, and she might get the bird.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Why prithee , let me be one of thine ants, and do it for me then. As I'm virtuous and a gentlewoman I'll restore.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Say no more 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: What manner of man is thy father? 'sfoot I'd fain see the witty monkey because thou sayst he's a poet: I'll tell thee, what I'll do: Leverpoole or Chartly, shall like my gentleman usher go to him, and say such a lady sends for him, about a sonnet or an epitaph for her child that died at nurse, or for some device about a mask or so; if he comes you shall stand in a corner, and see in what state I'll bear myself: he does not know me, nor my lodging.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Is't a match sirs? shall's be merry with him and his muse.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Agreed, any scaffold to execute knavery upon.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I'll send then my vaunt-courier presently: in the mean time, march after the captain, scoundrels, come hold me up:

lg.l: Look how Sabrina sunk ith' river Severn,
So will we four be drunk ith' shipwreck tavern. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Bellamont, Maybery, and mistress Maybery.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Come wife, our two gallants will be here presently: I have promised them the best of entertainment, with protestation never to reveal to thee their slander: I will have thee bear thyself, as if thou madest a feast upon Simon and Jude's day, to country gentlewomen, that came to see the pageant, bid them extremely welcome, though thou wish their throats cut; 'tis in fashion.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: O God I shall never endure them.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Endure them, you are a fool: make it your case, as it may be many women's of the freedom; that you had a friend in private, whom your husband should lay to his bosom: and he in requital should lay his wife to his bosom: what treads of the toe, salutations by winks, discourse by bitings of the lip, amorous glances, sweet stolen kisses when your husband's backs turned, would pass between them, bear yourself to Greenshield as if you did love him for affecting you so entirely, not taking any notice of his journey: they'll put more tricks upon you: you told me Greenshield means to bring his sister to your house, to have her board here.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Right, she's some cracked demi-culverin, that hath miscarried in service: no matter though it be some charge to me for a time I care not.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Lord was there ever such a husband?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Why, wouldst thou have me suffer their tongues to run at large, in ordinaries and cockpits; though the knaves do lie, I tell you master Bellamont, lies that come from stern looks, and satin outsides, and guilt rapiers also, will be put up and go for currant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Right sir, 'tis a small spark, gives fire to a beautiful woman's discredit.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p:
I will therefore use them like informing knaves in this kind, make up their mouths with ●iluer, and after be revenged upon them: I was in doubt I should have grown fat of late: and it were not for law suits: and fear of our wives, we rich men
should grow out of all compass: they come, my worthy friends welcome: look my wife's colour rises already.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: You have not made her acquainted with the discovery.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O by no means: ye see gentlemen the affection of an old man; I would fain make all whole again. Wife give entertainment to our new acquaintance, your lips wife, any woman may lend her lips without her husband's privity 'tis allowable.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You are very welcome; I think it be near dinner time gentlemen: I'll will the maid to cover, and return presently.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: God's precious why doth she leave them? Exit.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O I know her stomach: she is but retired into another chamber, to ease her heart with crying a little: it hath ever been her humour ▪ she hath done it 5. or 6. times in a day, when courtiers have been hear, if any thing hath been out of order, and yet every return laughed and been as merry: and how is it gentlemen, you are well acquainted with this room, are you not?

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: I had a delicate banquet once on that table.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: In good time: but you are better acquainted with my bed chamber.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Were the cloth of gold cushions set forth at your entertainment?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: And the cloth of tissue valance ▪

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: They are very rich ones.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: God refuse me, they are lying rascals, I have no such furniture.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I protest it was the strangest, and yet withal the happiest fortune that we should meet you two at Ware, that ever redeemed such desolate actions: I would not wrong you again for a million of London's.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: No, do you want any money? or if you be in debt, I am a hundreth pound ith' subsidy, command me.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Alas good gentleman; did you ever read of the like patience in any of your ancient Romans?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You see what a sweet face in a velvet cap can do, your citizens' wives are like partridges, the hens are better than the cocks.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: I believe it in troth, sir you did observe how the gentlewoman could not contain herself, when she saw us enter.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: For thus much I must speak in allowance of her modesty, when I had her most private she would blush extremely.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, I warrant you, and ask you if you would have such a great sin lie upon your conscience, as to lie with another man's wife.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Introth she would.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And tell you there were maids enough in London, if a man were so viciously given, whose portions would help them to husbands though gentlemen gave the first onset.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: You are a merry old gentleman in faith sir: much like to this was her language.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And yet clip you with as voluntary a bosom; as if she had fallen in love with you at some inns a court revels; and invited you by letter to her lodging.

sp.speaker: Fet.
sp.p: Your knowledge sir, is perfect without any information.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I'll go see what my wife is doing gentlemen, when my wife enters show her this ring; and 'twill quit all suspicion. Exit.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Dost hear Luke Greenshield will thy wife by here presently.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I left my boy to weight upon her, by this light, I think God provides; for if this citizen had not out of his overplus of kindness proffered her, her diet and lodging under the name of my sister, I could not have told what shift to have made; for the greatest part of my money is revolted; we'll make more use of him, the whoreson rich innkeeper of Doncaster her father showed himself a rank ostler: to send her up at this time a year; and and by the carrier to, 'twas but a jade's trick of him.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: But have you instructed her to call you brother.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Yes and she'll do it, I left her at bosom's inn, she'll be here, presently. Enter Maybery.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Master Greenshield your sister is come; my wife is entertaining her, by the mass I have been upon her lips already, lady you are welcome, look you master Greenshield, because your sister is newly come out of the fresh air, and that to be pent up in a narrow lodging here ith' city may offend her health she shall lodge at a garden house of mine in morefeilds where if it please you and my worthy friend hear to bear her company your several lodgings and joint commons (To the poor ability of a citizen) shall be provided.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: O God sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Nay no compliment your love's command it: shall's to dinner gentlemen, come master Bellamont I'll be the gentleman usher to this fair lady.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p:
Here is your ring mistress; a thousand times, — and
would have willingly lost my best of maintenance that I might have found you hair so tractable.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Sir I am still myself, I know not by what means you have grown upon my husband, he is much deceived in you I take it: will you go in to dinner — oh God that I might have my will of him and it were not for my husband I'd scratch out his eyes presently. Ex.

sp.speaker: Fet.
sp.p: Welcome to London bonny mistress Kate, thy husband little dreams of the familiarity that hath passed between thee and I Kate.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: No matter if he did: he ran away from me like a base slave as he was, out of Yorkshire, and pretended he would go the island voyage, since I ne'er heard of him till within this fortnight: can the world condemn me for entertaining a friend, that am used so like an infidel?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: I think not, but if your husband knew of this he'd be divorced.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: He were an ass then, no wise-men should deal by their wives as the sale of ordinance passeth in England, if it break the first discharge the workman is at the loss of it, if the second the merchant, and the workman jointly, if the third the merchant, so in our case, if a woman prove false the first year, turn her upon her father's neck, if the second, turn her home to her father but allow her a portion, but if she hold pure metal two year and fly to several pieces, in the third, repair the ruins of her honesty at your charges, for the best piece of ordinance, may be cracked in the casting, and for women to have cracks and slaves, alas they are born to them, now I have held out four year, doth my husband do any things about London doth he swagger?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: O as tame as a fray in Fleetestreet , when their are nobody to part them.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I ever thought so, we have notable valiant fellows about Doncaster, they'll give the lie and the stab both in an instant.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: You like such kind of manhood best Kate.

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Yes introth for I think any woman that loves her friend, had rather have him stand by it then lie by it, but I pray thee tell me, why must I be quartered at this citizens' garden house, say you.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: The discourse of that will set thy blood on fire to be revenged on thy husband's forehead piece. Ent. Bella. And maist. maybe.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Will you go in to dinner sir?

sp.speaker: Rat.
sp.p: Will you lead the way forsooth?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: No sweet forsooth we'll follow you.
O master Bellamont: as ever you took pity upon the simplicity of a poor abused gentlewoman: will you tell me one thing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Any thing sweet mistress Mayberry.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I but will you do it faithfully?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As I respect your acquaintance I shall do it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Tell me then I beseech you, do not you think this minx is some naughty pack whom my husband hath fallen in love with, and means to keep under my nose at his garden house.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No upon my life is she not,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O I cannot believe it, I know by her eyes she is not honest, why should my husband proffer them such kindness? that have abused him and me; so intolerable: and will not suffer me to speak; there's the hell on't not suffer me to speak.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fie fie, he doth that like a usurer, that will use a man with all kindness, that he may be careless of paying his money, upon his day, and afterwards take the extremity of the forfeiture; your jealousy is idle: say this were true, it lies in the bosom of a sweet wife to draw her husband from any loose imperfection, from wenching, from jealousy, from covetousness from crabbedness, which is the old man's common disease, by her politic yielding.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She may do it from crabbedness, for example I have known as tough blades as any are in England broke upon a featherbed, — come to dinner,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'll be ruled by you sir, for you are very like mine uncle.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Suspicion works more mischief grows more strong, to sever chaste beds then apparent wrongs. Exit.

div.head: Actus 3. Saena 1.
div.stage: Enter doll, Chartly Leverpoole and Phillip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Come my little punk with thy two compositors to this unlawful painting house, thy pounders a my old poetical dad will be here presently, take up thy state in this chair, and bear thyself as if thou wert talking to thy pothecary after the receipt of a purgation: look scurvily upon him: sometimes be merry and stand upon thy pantofles like a new elected scavenger.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: And by and by melancholic like a tilter that hath broke his staves foul before his mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Right, for he takes thee to be a woman of a great count: hark upon my life he's come.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: See who knocks: thou shalt see me make a fool of a poet, that hath made five hundred fools.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Please your new ladyship he's come.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Is he? I should for the more state let him walk some two hours in an utter room: if I did owe him money, 'twere not much out of fashion; but come enter him: stay, when we are in private conference send in my tailor.

div.stage: Enter Bellamont brought in by Leverpoole.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Look you my lady's asleep , she'll wake presently.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I come not to teach a starling sir, good-bye.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Nay, in truth sir, if my lady should but dream you had been hear.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Who's that keeps such a prating?

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: 'Tis I madam.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I'll have you preferred to be a crier: you have an exc'llent throat for't: pox a the poet is he not come yet?

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: He's here madam.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Cry you mercy: I ha' cursed my monkey for shrewd turns a hundred times, and yet I love it never the worse I protest.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Tis not in fashion dear lady to call the breaking out of a gentlewoman's lips, scabs, but the heat of the liver.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: So sir: if you have a sweet breath, and do not smell of sweaty linen, you may draw nearer, nearer.

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: I am no friend to garlic madam.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: You write the sweeter verse a great deal sir, I have heard much good of your wit master poet: you do many devises for citizens' wives: I care not greatly because I have a city laundress already, if I get a city poet too: I have such a device for you, and this it is. Enter tailor.o welcome tailor: do but wait till I dispatch my tailor, and I'll discover my device to you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'll take my leave of your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: No: I pray thee stay: I must have you sweat for my device master poet.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He sweats already believe it.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: A cup of wine there: what fashion will make a woman have the best body Taylor.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: A short Dutch waist with a round catherine-wheel farthingale: a close sleeve with a cartoose colour and a piccadill.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: And what meat will make a woman have a fine wit master poet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Foul madam is the most light, delicate, and witty feeding.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Foul sayst thou: I know them that feed of it every meal, and yet are as arrant fools as any are in a kingdom of my credit: hast thou done Taylor? now to discover my device sir: I'll drink to you sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: God's precious, we ne'er thought of her device before, pray god it be any thing tolerable.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I'll have you make 12. poesies for a dozen of cheese trenchers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O horrible!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: In Welsh madam?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Why in Welsh sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Because you will have them served in with your cheese lady.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I will bestow them indeed upon a Welsh captain: one that loves cheese better than venison, for if you should but get 3. or 4. Cheshire cheeses and set them a running down Highgate-hill, he would make more haste after them than after the best kennel of hounds in England; what think you of my device?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Fore-god a very strange device and a cunning one.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Now he begins to eye the goblet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You should be a kin to the Bellamonts, you give the same arms madam.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Faith I paid sweetly for the cup, as it may be you and some other gentleman have done for their arms.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, the same weight: the same fashion: I had three nest of them given me, by a nobleman at the christening of my son Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Your son is come to full age sir: and hath ta'en possession of the gift of his godfather.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ha, thou wilt not kill me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: No sir, I'll kill no poet lest his ghost write satires against me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What's she? A good common wealths woman, she was born.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: For her country, and has born her country.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Heart of virtue? what make I here?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: This was the party you railed on: I keep no worse company than yourself father, you were wont to say venery is like usury that it may be allowed though it be not lawful.

sp.speaker: Bael
sp.p: Wherefore come I hither.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: To make a device for cheese-trenchers.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I'll tell you why I sent for you, for nothing but to show you that your gravity may be drawn in: white hairs may fall into the company of drabs as well as red beards into the society of knaves: would not this woman deceive a whole camp ith' Low-countries, and make one commander believe she only kept her cabin for him, and yet quarter twenty more in't.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Prithee poet what dost thou think of me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I think thou art a most admirable, brave, beautiful whore.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Nay sir, I was told you would rail: but what do you think of my device sir, nay: but you are not to depart yet master poet: wilt sup with me? I'll cashier all my young barnicles, and we'll talk over a piece of mutton and a partridge, wisely.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sup with thee that art a common undertaker? thou that dost promise nothing but watchet eyes, bombast calves and false periwigs.

sp.speaker: Dol ▪
sp.p: Prithee comb thy beard with a comb of black lead, it may be I shall affect thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O thy unlucky star! I must take my leave of your worship I cannot fit your device at this instant: I must desire to borrow a nest of goblets of you: oh villainy! I would some honest butcher would beg all the queans and knaves ith' city and carry them into some other country they'd sell better than beeves and calves: what a virtuous city would this be then! marry I think there would be a few people left in't, uds foot, gulled with cheese-trenchers and yoked in entertainment with a tailor? good, good. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How dost Doll?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Scurvy, very scurvy.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Where shall's sup wench?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p:
I'll sup in my bed: get you home to your
lodging and come when I send for you, o filthy rogue that I am.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How! how, mistress Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Saint Antony's fire light in your Spanish slops: uds life, ille make you know a difference, between my mirth and melancholy, you panderly rogue.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: We observe your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: The punks in her humer — pax. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I'll humour you and you pox me: uds life have I lain with a Spaniard of late, that I have learned to mingle such water with my Malago, other's some scurvy thing or other breeding; how many several loves of players of vaulters, of lieutenants have I entertained besides a runner a the ropes, and now to let blood when the sign is at the heart? should I send him a letter with some jewel in't, he would requite it as lawyers do, that re-return a woodcock pie to their clients, when they send them a basin and a ewer, I will instantly go and make myself drunk, till I have lost my memory, live a scoffing poet? Exit.

div.stage: Enter leapfrog and Squirill.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.p: Now Squirrel wilt thou make us acquainted with the jest thou promised to tell us of?

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: I will discover it, not as a Derbyshire women discovers her great teeth, in laughter: but softly as a gentleman courts a wench behind an arras: and this it is, young Greenshield thy master with Greenshield's sister lie in my master's garden-house here in Morefields.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.p: Right, what of this?

sp.speaker: Squir
sp.p: Marry sir if the gentlewoman be not his wife, he commits incest, for I'm sure he lies with her every night.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: All this I know, but to the rest.

sp.speaker: Squir.
sp.p: I will tell thee, the most politic trick of a woman, that ere made a man's face look withered and pale like the tree in cuckold's haven in a great snow: and this it is, my mistress makes her husband believe that she walks in her sleep a nights, and to confirm this belief in him, sundry times she hath risen out of her bed, unlocked all the doors, gone from chamber to chamber, opened her chests, toused among her linen, and when he hath waked and missed her, coming to question why she conjured thus at midnight, he hath found her fast asleep , marry it was cat's sleep, for you shall hear what prey she watched for.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.p: Good; forth.

sp.speaker: Squir.
sp.p: I overheard her last night talking with thy master, and she promised him that as soon as her husband was asleep , she would walk according to her custom, and come to his chamber, marry she would do it so puritannically, so secretly I mean that nobody should hear of it.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Squir.
sp.p: Take but that corner and stand close, and thine eyes shall w●t● esse it.

sp.speaker: Frog.
sp.p: O intolerable wit, what hold can any man take of a woman's honesty.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: Hold? no more hold then of a bull anointed with soap, and baited with a shoal of fiddlers in Staffordshire: stand close I hear her coming. Enter Kate.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: What a filthy knave was the shoemaker, that made my slippers, what a creaking they keep: oh lord, if there be any power that can make a woman's husband sleep soundly at a pinch, as I have often read in foolish poetry that there is, now, now, and it be thy will, let him dream some fine dream or other, that he's made a knight, or a nobleman, or somewhat whilst I go and take but two kisses, but two kisses from sweet Fetherstone. Exit.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: 'Sfoot he may well dream he's made a knight: for I'll be hanged if she do not dub him.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Was there ever any walking spirit, like to my wife? what reason should there be in nature for this ▪ I will question some ●●●●tion: not hear neither: udslife, I would laugh if she were in master Fetherstone's chamber, she would fright him, master Fetherstone, master Fetherstone.

sp.speaker: Within feather
sp.p: Ha, how now who calls?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Did you leave your door open last night?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: I know not, I think my boy did.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: God's light she's there then, will you know the jest, my wife hath her old tricks, I'll hold my life, my wife's in your chamber, rise out of your bed, and see and you can feel her.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: He will feel her ● warrant you?

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Have you her sir?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Not yet sir, she's here sir.

div.stage: Enter Fetherstone and Kate in his arms.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p:
So I said even now to myself before God la: take her up in your arms, and bring her hither softly, for fear of waking
her: I never knew the like of this before God la, alas poor Kate, look before God; she's asleep with her eyes open: pretty little rogue, I'll wake her, and make her ashamed of it.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: O you'll make her sicker then.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I warrant you; would all women thought no more hurt than thou dost, now sweet villain, Kate, Kate.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I longed for the merry thought of a pheasant.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: She talks in her sleep.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: And the foul-gutted tripewife had got it, and eat half of it: and my colour went and came, and my stomach wambled: till I was ready to sound, but a midwife perceived it, and marked which way my eyes went; and helped me to it, but lord how I picked it, 'twas the sweetest meat methought .

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: O politic mistress.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Why Kate, Kate?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I beshrew your heart, lord where am I?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I pray thee be not frighted.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O I am sick, I am sick, I am sick, oh how my flesh trembles: o some of the Angelica water, I shall have the mother presently.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Hold down her stomach good master Fetherstone, while I fetch some. Exit.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Well dissembled Kate.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Pish, I am like some of your ladies that can be sick when they have no stomach to lie with their husbands.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: What mischivous fortune is this: we'll have a journey to Ware Kate, to redeem this misfortune.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Well, cheaters do not win all ways: that woman that will entertain a friend, must as well provide a closet or backdoor for him, as a featherbed.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Be my troth I pity thy husband.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Pity him, no man dares call him cuckold; for he wears satin: pity him, he that will pull down a man's sign, and set up horns, there's law for him.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Be sick again, your husband comes.

div.stage: Enter Greeneshield with a broken shin.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I have the worst luck; I think I get more bumps and shrewd turns ith' dark, how does she master Fetherstone.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Very ill sir; she's troubled with the mother extremely, I held down her belly even now, and I might feel it rise ▪

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O lay me in my bed, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: I will find a remedy for this walking, if all the doctors in town can sell it; a thousand pound to a penny she spoil not her face, or break her neck, or catch a cold that she may ne'er claw off again, how dost wench?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: A little recovered; alas I have so troubled that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: None ith' world Kate, may I do you any farther service.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: And I were where I would be in your bed: pray pardon me, wast you master Fetherstone, hem, I should be well then.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: Mark how she wrings him by the fingers.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Good night, pray you give the gentleman thanks for patience.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Good night sir.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: You have a shrewd blow, you were best have it searched.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: A scratch, a scratch. Exit.

sp.speaker: Feth
sp.p: Let me see what excuse should I frame, to get this wench forth a town with me: I'll persuade her husband to take physic, and presently have a letter framed, from his father in law, to be delivered that morning for his wife, to come and receive some small parcel of money in Enfield chase, at a keeper's that is her uncle, than sir he not being in case to travel, will entreat me to accompany his wife, we'll lie at Ware all night, and the next morning to London, I'll go strike a tinder, and frame a letter presently. Exit.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: And I'll take the pains to discover all this to my master old Maybery, there hath gone a report a good while, my master hath used them kindly, because they have been over familiar with his wife, but I see which way Fetherstone looks. sfoot there's ne'er a gentleman of them all shall gull a citizen, and think to go scotfree: though your commons shrink for this be but secret, and my master shall entertain thee, make thee instead of handling false dice, finger nothing but gold and silver wag, an old servingman turns to a young beggar, whereas a young prentice may turn to an old alderman, will't be secret?

sp.speaker: Leap.
sp.p: O God sir, as secret as rushes in an old lady's chamber. Exit.

div.head: Actus 4. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter Bellamont in his nightcap, with leaves in his hand, his man after him with lights, Standish and paper.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sirrah, I'll speak with none.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Not a player:

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No though a sharer ball,
I'll speak with none although it be the mouth
Of the big company, I'll speak with none, — away.
sp.p: Why should not I be an excellent statesman? I can in the writing of a tragedy, make Caesar speak better than ever his ambition could: when I write of Pompey I have Pompey's soul within me, and when I personate a worthy poet, I am then truly myself, a poor unpreferred scholar.

div.stage: Enter his man hastily.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Here's a swaggering fellow sir, that speaks not like a man of gods making, swears he must speak with you and will speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bael
sp.p: Not of gods making what is he? A cuckold?

sp.speaker: Servant ▪
sp.p: He's a gentleman sir, by his clothes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Enter him and his clothes: clothes sometimes are better gentlemen than their masters. Ent. the captain and the Ser.is this he? Seek you me sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I seek sir, (God pless you) for a sentillman, that talks besides to himself when he's alone, as if he were in bedlam, and he's a poet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So sir it may be you seek me, for I'm sometimes out a my wits.

sp.speaker: C●p
sp.p: You are a poet sir, are you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I'm haunted with a fury sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Pray master poet shoot off this little potgun, and I will conjure your fury: 'tis well lay you sir, my desires are to have some amiable and amorous sonnet or madrigal composed by your fury, see you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Are you a lover sir of the nine muses.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Owe, by gad out a cry.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You're then a scholar sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I ha' picked up my crumbs in Jesus college in Oxford one day a gad while ag●e ▪

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You're welcome you're very welcome, I'll borrow your judgement look you sir, I'm writing a tragedy, the tragedy of young Astyanax.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: S●●●nax tragedy is he living can you tell? was not Stianax a mammoth man?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O no sir, you mistake, he was a Trojan great Hector's son.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Hector was grannam to Cadwallader, when she was great with child, god udge me, there was one young Styanan of Monmouthshire was a madder Greek as any is in all England.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: This was not he assure ye: look you sir, I will have this tragedy presented in the French court, by French gallants.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By god your Frenchmen will do a tragedy interlude, poggy well.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It shall be sir at the marriages of the Duke of Orleans, and Chatilion the admiral of France, the stage.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Uds blood, does Orleans marry with the admiral of France now.

sp.speaker: Bael
sp.p: O sir no, they are two several marriages. As I was saying the stage hung all with black velvet, and while 'tis acted, myself will stand behind the Duke of Biron, or some other chief minion or so, — who shall, I they shall take some occasion about the music of the fourth act, to step to the French King, and say, sire, voyla, il et votre tres-humble seruiteur, le plus sage, è divin● espirit, monsieur Bellamont, all in French thus pointing at me, or you is the learned old English gentleman master Bellamont a very worthy man, to be one of your privy chamber, or poet laureate.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But are you sure Duke pepper-noon will give you such good urdes, behind your back to your face.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O ay, ay, I man, he's the only courtier that I know there: but what do you think that I may come to by this.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: God udge me, all France may hap die in your debt for this.

sp.speaker: Bael
sp.p: I am now writing the description of his death.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Did he die in his ped ▪

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You shall hear: suspicion is the minion of great hearts, no: I will not begin there: imagine a great man were to be executed about the 7. hour in a gloomy morning.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: As it might be Sampson or so, or great Golias that was killed by my countryman.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Right sir, thus I express it in young Astyanax.
Now the wild people greedy of their griefs,
Longing to see, that which their thoughts abhorred,
Prevented day, and rod on their own roofs.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Could the little horse that ambled on the top of paulest carry all the people; else how could they ride on the roofs!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O sir, 'tis a figure in poetry, mark how 'tis followed,
Rod on their own roofs,
Making all neighbouring houses tilled with men; tiled with men ●ist not good.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By Sesu, and it were tiled all with naked imen 'twere better.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You shall hear no more; pick your ears, they are foul sir, what are you sir pray?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A captain sir, and a follower of god Mars.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Mars, Bacchus, and I love Apollo! A captain! then I pardon your sir, and captain what would you press me for?

sp.speaker: Captain
