sp.p: For a witty ditty, to a gentlewoman, that I am fallen in with all, over head and ears in affections, and natural desires.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: An acrostic were good upon her name methinks .

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Crosse sticks: I would not be too cross master poet; yet if it be best to bring her name in question, her name is mistress Dorothy Hornet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The very consumption that wastes my son, and the aim that hung lately upon me: do you love this mistress Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Love her! there is no captain's wife in England, can have more love put upon her, and yet I'm sure captains wives, have their pellies full of good men's loves.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: And does she love you? has there passed any great matter between you?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: As great a matter, as a whole coach, and a horse and his wife are gone to and fro between us.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Is she? i'faith captain, be valiant and tell truth, is she honest?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Honest? god udge me, she's as honest, as a punk, that cannot abide fornication, and lechery.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Look you captain, I'll show you why I ask, I hope you think my wenching days are past, yet sir, here's a letter that her father, brought me from her and enforced me to take this very day. Enter a servant and whispers.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Tis for some love — song to send to me, I hold my life.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: This falls out pat, my man tells me, the party is at my door, shall she come in captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O ay, ay, put her in, put her in I pray now. Exit Seru.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The letter says here, that she's exceeding sick, and entreats me to visit her: captain, lie you in ambush behind the hangings, and perhaps you shall hear the piece of a comedy: she comes, she comes, make yourself away.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Does the poet play Torkin and cast my Lucretia's water too in huggermuggers ? if he do, Styanax tragedy was never so horrible bloody-minded, as his comedy shall be, — Tawson's captain Jenkin's. Enter doll.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Now master poet, I sent for you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And I came once at your ladyship's call.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: My ladyship and your lordship lie both in one manner; you have conjured up a sweet spirit in me have you not rhymer?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why Medea! what spirit! would I were a young man for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: So would I, for then thou couldst do me no hurt; now thou dost.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If I were a younker, it would be no immodesty in me to be seen in thy company; but to have snow in the lap of June; vile! vile: yet come; garlic has a white head, and a green stalk, then why should not ▪ I? let's be merry: what says the devil to all the world, for I'm sure thou art carnally possessed with him.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Thou hast a filthy foot, a very filthy carrier's foot.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A filthy shoe, but a fine foot, I stand not upon my foot I.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What stands he upon then? with a pox god bless us?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: A leg and a calf! I have had better of a butcher forty times for carrying a body! not worth begging by a barber-surgeon.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Very good, you draw me and quarter me, fates keep me from hanging.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p:
And which most turns up a woman's stomach, thou art an old hoary man: thou hast gone over the bridge of many years, and now art ready to drop into a grave: what do I see then
in that withered face of thine?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Wrinkles: gravity.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Wretchedness: grief: old fellow thou hast be witch me; I can neither eat for thee, nor sleep for thee, nor lie quietly in my bed for thee.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Uds blood! I did never see a white flea before I will cling you?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I was born sure in the dog days I'm so unlucky; ay, in whom neither a flaxen hair, yellow beard, French doublet, nor Spanish hose, youth nor personage, rich ●ace nor money cold ever breed a true love to any, ever to any man, am now besotted, dote, am mad, for the carcase of a man, and as if I were a bawd, no ring pleases me but a death's head.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sesu, are I men so arsy-varsy .

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Mad for me? why if the worm of lust were wriggling within me as it does in others, dost think I'd crawl upon thee; would I low after thee, that art a common calf-bearer.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I confess it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Do you, are you a town cow and confess you bear calves.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I confess, I have been an inn for any guest.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A pogs a your stable-room; is your inn a bawdy house now?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: I confess (For I ha' been taught to hide nothing from my surgeon and thou art he) I confess that old stinking surgeon like thyself) whom I call father, that Hornet never sweat for me, I'm none of his making.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You lie he makes you a punk Hornet minor.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: He's but a cheater, and I the false die he plays withal, I power all my poison out before thee, because hereafter I will be clean: shun me not, loathe me not, mock me not, plagues confound thee, I hate thee to the pit of hell, yet if thou goest thither, I'll follow thee, run, aid do what thou canst, I'll run and ride over the world after thee.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Cockatrice: you mistress salamanders that fear no burning, let my mare and my mare's horse, and my coach come running home again and run to an hospital, and your surgeons, and to knaves and panders and to the tiuell and his tame to.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Fiend art thou razed to torment me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: She loves you captain honestly.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I'll have any man, oman or child by his ears, that says a common drab can love a sentillman honestly, I will sell my coach for a cart to have you to punk's hall, Pridewell, I sarge you in Apollo's name, whom you belong to, see her forthcoming, till I come and tiggle her, by and by, 'sblood I was never cozened with a more rascal piece of mutton, since I came out a the lawer countries. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My doors are open for thee, be gone: woman!

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: This goats — pizzle of thine —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Away: I love no such implements in my house.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Dost not? am I but an implement? by all the maidenheads that are lost in London in a year (And that's a great oath) for this trick, other manner of women than myself shall come to this house only to laugh at thee; and if thou wouldst labour thy heart out, thou shalt not do withal. Exit.Enter servant.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Is this my poetical fury? how now sir!

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Master Maybery and his wife sir ith' next room.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What are they doing sir?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Nothing sir, that I see, but only would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Enter 'em: this house will be too hot for me, if this wench cast me into these sweats, I must shift myself, for pure necessity, haunted with sprites in my old days!

div.stage: Enter Maybery booted, his wife with him.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: A comedy, a Canterbury tale smells not half so sweet as the comedy I have for thee old poet: thou shalt write upon't poet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay I will write upon't if't be a comedy, for I have been at a most villainous female tragedy: come, the plot, the plot.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Let your man give you the boots presently, the plot lies in Ware my white poet: wife thou and I this night, will have mad sport in Ware, mark me well wife, in Ware.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: At your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Nay it shall be at your pleasure wife: look you sir, look you: Fetherstone's boy (Like an honest crack-halter) laid open all to one of my prentices, (For boys you know like women love to be doing.)

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Very good: to the plot.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Fetherstone like a crafty muttonmonger, persuades Greenshield to be run through the body.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Strange! through the body?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I man, to take physic ▪ he does so, he's put to his purgation; then sir what does me Fetherstone, but counterfeits a letter from an innkeeper of Doncaster, to fetch Greenshield (Who is needy you know) to a keeper's lodge in Enfield-chase ▪ a certain uncle, where Greenshield should receive money due to him in behalf of his wife.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: His wife! is Greenshield married? I have heard him swear he was a bachelor.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: So have I a hundred times.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: The knave has more wives than the Turk, he has a wife almost in every shire in England, this parcel gentlewoman is that innkeepers daughter of Doncaster.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Hath she the entertainment of her forefathers? will she keep all comer's company?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: She help's to pass away stale capons, sour wine, and musty provender: but to the purpose, this train was laid by the baggage herself and Fetherstone, who it seems makes her husband a unicorn: and to give fire to't, Greenshield like an arrant wittal entreats his friend, to ride before his wife, and fetch the money, because taking bitter pills, he should prove but a loose fellow if he went, and so durst not go.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And so the poor stag is to be hunted in Enfield-chase

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: No sir, master poet there you miss the plot. Fetherstone and my lady Greenshield are rid to batter away their light commodities in Ware, Enfield-chase is too cold for 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: In ware!

sp.speaker: M●y
sp.p: In dirty ware: I forget myself wise, on with your ryding suit and cry northward ho, as the boy at Paul's says, let my prentice get up before thee, and m●n t●ee to Ware, lodge in the ●●ne I told thee, spur cut and away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Well sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Stay, stay, what's the bottom of this riddle? why send you her away?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p:
For a thing my little hoary poet: look thee, I smelled out my noble stinker Greenshield in his chamber, and as though
my heart strings had been cracked, I wept, and sighed, and thumped, and thumped, and raved and ranted, and railed, and told him how my wife was now grown as common as bribery, and that she had hired her tailor to ride with her to Ware, to meet a gentleman of the court.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Good; and how took he this drench down.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Like eggs and muscadine, at a gulp: he cries out presently, did not I tell you old man, that she win my game when she came to bearing? he rails upon her, wills me to take her in the act; to put her to her white sheet, to be divorced, and for all his guts are not fully scoured by his pothecary, he's pulling on his boots, and will ride along with us; let's muster as many as we can.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It will be excellent sport, to see him and his own wife meet in Ware, wilt not? Ay, ay, we'll have a whole regiment of horse with us.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I stand upon thorns, tell I shake him byth' hor●es: come, boots boy, we must gallop all the way, for the sin you know is done with turning up the white of an eye, will you join your forces.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Like a Hollander against a Dunkirk.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.l: March then, this curse is on all lechers thrown,
They give horns and at last, horns are their own. Exit.

div.stage: Enter captain Jenkin's, and Allom.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Set the best of your little diminutive legs before, and ride post I pray.

sp.speaker: Allo.
sp.p: Is it possible that mistress D●ll should be so bad?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Possible! S●ould 'tis more easy for an oman to be naught, than for a soldier to beg, and that's horrible easy, you know.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I but to coney-catch us all so grossly.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Your Norfolk tumblers are but zanies to coney-catching punks.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: She gelded my purse of fifty pounds in ready money.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
I will geld all the horses in five hundred shires, but I will ride over her, and her cheaters, and her hornets; she made a stark ass of my coach-horse, and there is a butterbox, whom she spread thick upon her white bread, and eat him up, I think she has sent the poor fellow to Gilderland, but I will marse pravely in and out, and pack
again upon all the low countries in Christendom, as holland and Zeland and Netherland, and Cleveland too, and I will be drunk and cast with master Hans van Belch, but I will smell him out.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: Do so and we'll draw all our arrows of revenge up to the head but we'll hit her for her villainy.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I will traw as better, and as urse weapons as arrewes up to the head, lug you, it shall be warrants to give her the whip deedle.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: But now she knows she's discovered, she'll take her bells and fly out of our reach.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Fie with her bells! 'ounds I know a parish that sal tag down all the bells and sell 'em to captain Jenkens, to do him good ▪ and if pelle will fly, we'll fly too, unless, the pell-ropes hang us: will you amble up and down to master justice by my side, to have this rascal Hornet in corum, and so, to make her hold her whore's peace.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: I'll amble or trot with you captain: you told me, she threatened her champions should cut for her, if so, we may have the peace of her.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O mon du! U dguin! follow your leader, jenken shall cut, and slice, as worse as they: come I scorn to have any peace of her, or of any woman, but open wars. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Bellamont, Maybery, Greensheild, Phillip, Levarpoole, Chartley: all booted.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What? will these young gentlemen to help us to catch this fresh salmon, ha! Philip! are they thy friends.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Yes sir ▪

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We are beholding to you gentlemen that you'll fill our consort I ho seen your faces methinks before; and I cannot inform myself where.

sp.speaker: Both,
sp.p: May be so sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Shall's to horse, hears a tickler: heigh: to horse.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Come switts and spurs! let's mount our chevals: merry quoth a.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Gentlemen shall I shoot a fool's bolt out among you all, because we'll be sure to be merry.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: For mirth on the high way, will make us rid ground faster than if thieves were at our tails, what say ye to this, let's all practise jests one against another, and he that has the best jest thrown upon him, and is most galled, between our riding forth and coming in, shall bear the charge of the whole journey.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Content i'faith.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We shall fit one a you with a coxcomb at Ware I believe.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Is't a wreath.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: And hands clapped upon it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Stay, yonder's the dolphin without Bishopsgate, where our horses are at rack and manger, and we are going passed it: come cross over: and what place is this?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Bedlam is't not?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Where the madmen are, I never was amongst them, as you love me gentlemen, let's see what Greeks are within.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: We shall stay too long.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not a whit, ware will stay for our coming I warrant you: come a spurt and away, let's be mad once in our days: this is the door. Enter Full-moon.

sp.speaker: May,
sp.p: Save you sir, may we see some a your mad-folks, do you keep 'em?

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray bestow your name sir upon us.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: My name is Full-moon.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You well deserve this office good master Full-moon: and what madcaps have you in your house,

div.stage: Enter the physician.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: Divers.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: God's so, see, see, what's he walks yonder, is he mad.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: That's a musician, yes he's besides himself.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A musician, how fell he mad for god's sake?

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: For love of an Italian dwarf.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Has he been in Italy then?

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: Yes and speaks they say all manner of languages.

div.stage: Enter the ba●d.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: God's so, look, look, what's she.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The dancing bear: a pretty well-favoured little woman.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: They say, but I know not, that she was a bawd, and was frighted out of her wits by fire,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: May we talk with 'em master Full-moon

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: Yes and you will; I must look about for I have unruly tenants. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What have you in this paper honest friend?

sp.speaker: 'gree
sp.p: Is this he has all manner of languages, yet speaks none

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: How do you sir Andrew, will you send for some aquavit for me, I have had no drink never since the last great rain that fell.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No that's a lie.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Nay by gad, than you lie, for all you're sir Andrew, I was a dapper rogue in Portingale voyage, not an inch broad at the heel, and yet thus high, I scorned I can tell you to be drunk with rain water then sir, in those golden and silver days: I had sweet bits then sir Andrew: how do you good brother Timothy?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: You have been in much trouble since that voyage.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Never in Bridewell I protest, as I'm a virgin: for I could never abide that Bridewell I protest, I was once sick, and I took my water in a basket, and carried it to a doctor's.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: In a basket.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Yes sir: you arrant fool there was a urinal in it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: The doctor told me I was with child, how many lords knights, gentlemen, citizens, and others promised me to be godfathers to that child: 'twas not God's will: the prentices made a riot upon my glass-windows the Shrove-tuesday following and I miscarried.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: O do not weep.

sp.speaker: ●aud.
sp.p: I ha' cause to weep: I trust gentlewomen their diet sometimes a fortnight: lend gentlemen holland shirts, and they sweat 'em out at tennis: and no restitution, and no restitution ▪ but I'll take a new order, I will have but six stewed prunes in a dish and some of mother walls cakes: for my best customers are tailors.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Tailors! ha ha.

sp.speaker: ●aud.
sp.p: I tailors: give me your London prentice; your country gentlemen are grown too politic.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But what say you to such young gentlemen as these are.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
●oh, they as soon as they come to their lands get up to London, and like squibs that run upon lines, they keep
a spitting of fire, and cracking till they ha' spent all, and when my squib is out, what says his punk, foh, he stinks.

lg.l: Methought this other night, I saw a pretty sight,
A comely country maid, not squeamish nor afraid,
I sold her maidenhead once, and I sold her maidenhead twice,
And I should it last to an alderman of York.
And then I had sold it thrice.

sp.speaker: Musician
sp.p: You sing scuruily.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Marry muff, sing thou better, for I'll go sleep my old sleeps. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What are you a doing my friend.

sp.speaker: Musician
sp.p: Pricking, pricking.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What do you mean by pricking?

sp.speaker: Musician
sp.p: A gentleman like quality.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This fellow is some what prouder, and sullener than the other.

sp.speaker: May,
sp.p: O; so be most of your musicians.

sp.speaker: Musician
sp.p: Are my teeth rotten?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Musician
sp.p: Then I am no comfit-maker, nor vintner, I do not get wenches in my drink: are you a musician?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Musician
sp.p: We'll be sworn brothers then, look you sweet rogue.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: God's so, now I think upon't, a jest is crept into my head, steal away, if you love me. Exeunt: musician sings.

sp.speaker: Musician
sp.p: Was ever any merchant's band set better I set it: walk I'm a cold, this white satin is too thin unless it be cut, for then the sun enters: can you speak italian too, sapete italiano.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Un poco.

sp.speaker: Musician
sp.p: 'Sblood if it be in you, I'll poike it out if you; un poco, come march lie hear with me but till the fall of the lease, and if you have but poco italiano in you, I'll fill you full of more poco march.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come on. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Maybery, greenshield, Phillip. Full-moon. Leverpoole, and Chartely.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Good master Mayberry, Philip, if you be kind gentlemen uphold the jest: your whole voyage is paid for.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Follow it then.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: The old gentleman say you, why he talked even now as well in his wits as I do myself, and looked as wisely.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: No matter how he talks, but his pericranion's perished.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: Where is he pray?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Marry with the musician, and is madder by this time

sp.speaker: Ch●er.
sp.p: He's an excellent musician himself, you must note that.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: And having met one fit for his one tooth: you see he skips from us.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: The troth is master full-moon, divers trains have been laid to bring him hither, without gaping of people, and never any took effect till now.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: How fell he mad?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: For a woman, look you sir: here's a crown to provide his supper: he's a gentleman of a very good house, you shall be paid well if you convert him; tomorrow morning, bedding, and a gown shall be sent in, and wood and coal.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: Nay sir, he must ha' no fire.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: No, why look what straw you buy for him, shall return you a whole harvest.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Let his straw be fresh and sweet we beseech you sir?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Get a couple of your sturdiest fellows, and bind him I pray, whilst we slip out of his sight.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: I'll hamper him, I warrant gentlemen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: But how will my noble poet take it at my hands, to betray him thus.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Foh, 'tis but a jest, he comes.

div.stage: Enter musician and Bellamont.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Perdonate mi, si Io dimando del vostro nome: o, whether shrunk you: I have had such a mad dialogue here.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: We ha' been with the other mad folks.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: And what says he and his pricksong?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We were up to the ears in italian i'faith.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: In Italian; oh good master Bellamont let's hear him.

div.stage: Enter Full-moon, and two keepers.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How now, 'sdeath what do you mean? are you mad?

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: Away sirrah, bind him, hold fast: you want a wench sirrah, do you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What wench? will you take mine arms from me, being no heralds? let go you dogs.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: Bind him, be quiet: come, come, dogs, fie, and a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Master Maibery, Philip, master Maibery, uds foot.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: I'll bring you a wench, are you mad for a wench.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I hold my life my comrades have put this fool's cap upon thy head: to gull me: I smell it now: why do you hear Full-moon, let me lose; for I'm not mad; I'm not mad by Jesu:

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: Ask the gentlemen that.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Byth' lord I'm as well in my wits, as any man ith' house, and this is a trick put upon thee by these gallants in pure knavery.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: I'll try that, answer me to this question: lose his arms a little, look you sir, three geese nine pence; every goose three pence, what's that a goose, roundly, roundly one with another.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Sfoot do you bring your geese for me to cut up.

div.stage: Enter all.
Strike him soundly, and kick him.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Hold, hold, bind him master Full-moon.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: Bind him you, he has paid me all, I'll have none of his bonds not I, unless I could recover them better.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Have I given it you master poet, did the limebush take.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: It was his warrant sent thee to bedlam, old Jack Bellamont, and master Full-ith'moone, our warrant discharges him; poet, we'll all ride upon thee to Ware, and back again I fear to thy cost.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If you do, I must bear you, thank you master Greenshield, I will not die in your debt: farewell you mad rascals, to horse come, 'tis well done; 'twas well done, you may laugh, you shall laugh gentlemen: if the gudgeon had been swallowed by one of you it had been vile, but by gad 'tis nothing, for your best poets indeed are mad for the most part: farewell goodman Full-moon.

sp.speaker: Full-moon
sp.p: Pray gentlemen if you come by call in. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, yes, when they are mad, horse yourselves now if you be men.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.l: He gallop must that after women rides,
Get our wives out of town, they take long strides. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus 5. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter old Maybery and Bellamont.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p:
But why have you brought us to the wrong inn? and withal possessed Greenshield that my wife is not in town: when my project was, that I would have brought him up into the
chamber, where young Fetherstone and his wife lay: and so all his artillery should have recoiled into his own bosom.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O it will fall out far better, you shall see my revenge will have a more neat and unexpected conveyance: he hath been all up and down the town, to inquire for a Londoners wife, none such is to be found: for I have mewed your wife up already. marry he he●es of a Yorkshire gentlewoman at next inn, and that's all the commodity ware affords at this instant: now sir, he very politicly imagines, that your wife is ●ode to Puckridge, five mile further, for saith he in such a town where hosts will be familiar, and tapsters saucy, and chamberlains worse than thieves intelligencers, they'll never put foot out of stirrup: either at Puckridge or wades-mill (Saith he) you shall find them: and because our horses are weary, he's gone to take up post-horse : my counsel is only this, when he comes in, feign yourself very melancholy, swear you will ride no farther, and this is your part of the comedy: the sequel of the jest shall come like money borrowed of a courtier, and paid within the day, a thing strange and unexpected. Enter Greeneshield.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Enough, I ha't,

sp.speaker: Bel
sp.p: He comes.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Come gallants, the post-horse are ready, 'tis but a quarter of an hours riding, we'll ferret them and ●●ke them in-faith.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Are they grown politic? when do you see honesty covet corners, or a gentleman that's no thief lie in the inn of a carrier.

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: Nothing hath undone my wife, but too much riding.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: She was a printy piece of a poet indeed, and in her discourse would as many of your goldsmiths wives do, draw her simile from precious stones, so wittily, as redder than your ruby, harder than your diamond, and so from stone to stone, in less time than a man can draw on a straight boot, as if she had been an excellent lapidary.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Come will you to horse sir?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: No let her go to the devil and she will, I'll not stir a foot further.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: God's precious is't come to this: persuade him as you are a gentleman, there will be ballads made of him, and the burden thereof will be, if you had rode out 5. mile forward, he had found the fatal house of Brainford northward, oh hone, hone, hone ononero.

sp.speaker: Bell,
sp.p: You are merry sir.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Like your citizen, I never think of my debts, when I am a horseback.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You imagine you are riding from your creditors.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Good in faith: will you to horse?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I'll ride no further.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Then I'll discharge the postmaster: was't not a pretty wit of mine master poet to have had him rod into Puckridge, with a horn before him, ha wast not?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Good sooth excellent: I was dull in apprehending it: but come since we must stay: we'll be merry, chamberlain call in the music, bid the tapsters and maids come up and dance, what we'll make a night of it, hark you masters, I have an excellent jest to make old Maibery merry, sfoot we'll have him merry.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Let's make him drunk then, a simple catching wit I.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Go thy ways, I know a nobleman would take such a delight in thee.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Why so he would in his fool.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Before God but he would make a difference, he would keep you in satin, but as I was a saying we'll have him merry: his wife is gone to Puckridge, 'tis a wench makes him melancholy, 'tis a wench must make him merry: we must help him to a wench. when your citizen comes into his inn, wet and cold, dropping, either the hostis or one of her maids, warms his bed, pulls on his nightcap, cuts his corns puts out the candle, bids him command ought, if he want ought: and so after master citiner sleeps as quietly, as if he lay in his own Low-country of Holland, his own linen I mean sir, we must have a wench for him.

sp.speaker: 'gree
sp.p: But where's this wench to be found, here are all the movable petticoats of the house.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: At the next inn there lodged tonight —

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: God's precious a Yorkshire gentlewoman; I have't, I'll angle for her presently, we'll have him merry.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Procure some chamberlain to pander for you.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: No I'll be pander myself, because we'll be merry.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Will you, will you?

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: But how? be a pander as I am a gentleman? that were horrible, I'll thrust myself into the outside of a falconer in town here: and now I think on't there are a company of country players, that are come to town here, shall furnish me with hair and beard: if I do not bring her, — will be wondrous merry.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: About it look you sir, though she bear her far aloof, and her body out of distance, so her mind be coming 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Get old Maibery merry: that any man should take to heart thus the down fall of a woman, I think when he comes home poor snail, he'll not dare to peep forth of doors lest his horns usher him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Go thy ways, there be more in England wear large ears and horns, than stags and asses: excellent he rides post with a halter about his neck.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: How now wilt take?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Beyond expectation: I have persuaded him the only way to make you merry, is to help you to a wench, and the fool is gone to pander his own wife hither.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Why he'll know her?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: She hath been masked ever since she came into the inn, for fear of discovery.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Then she'll know him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: For that his own unfortunate wit helped my lazy invention, for he hath disguised himself like a falconer, in town hear, hoping in that procuring shape, to do more good upon her, then in the outside of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Young Fetherstone will know him?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: He's gone into the town, and will not return this half hour.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Excellent if she would come.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay upon my life she'll come: when she enters remember some of your young blood, talk as some of your gallant commoners will, dice and drink: freely: do not call for sack, lest it betray the coldness of your manhood, but fetch a caper now and then, to make the gold chink in your pockets: I so.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Ha old poet, let's once stand to it for the credit of Milk-street. Is my wife acquainted with this.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: She's perfect, and will come out upon her cue, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Good wenches in faith: fills some more sack hear.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: God's precious, do not call for sack by any means.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Why then give us a whole lordship for life in Rhenish, with the reversion in sugar,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: It were not amiss if we were dancing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Out upon't, I shall never do it.

div.stage: Enter Greensheild disguised, with mistress Greensheild.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p:
Out of mine nostril's tapster, thou smell'st like guild-hall two days after Simon and I●de, of drink most horribly, off with
thy mask sweet sinner of the North: these masks are foils to good faces, and to bad ones they are like new satin outsides to lousy linings.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: O by no means sir, your merchant will not open a whole piece to his best customer, he that buys a woman, must take her as she falls: I'll unmask my hand hears the sample.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Go to then, old poet I have ta'en her up already as a pinnace bound for the straits, she knows her burden yonder.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Lady you are welcome: you is the old gentleman and observe him, he's not one of your fat city chuffs: whose great belly argues that the felicity of his life consists in capon, sack, and sincere honesty, but a lean spare bountiful gallant one that hath an old wife, and a young performance: whose reward is not the rate of a captain newly come out of the Low-countries: or a Yorkshire attorney in good contentious practice, some angel, no the proportion of your wealthy citizen to his wench, is, her chamber, her diet, her physic, her apparel, her painting, her monkey, her pandar, her every thing. You'll say your young gentleman, is your only service that lies before you like a calf's head, with his brains some half yard from him, but I assure you, they must not only have variety of foolery; but also of wenches: whereas your conscionable graybeard of Farrington within, will keep himself, to the ruins of one cast waiting-woman an age: and perhaps, when he's passed all other good works, to wipe out false weights, and twenty ith' hundred, marry her —

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: O well bold Tom () we have precedents, for't ▪

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But I have a husband sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You have, if the knave thy husband be rich, make him poor, that he may borrow money of this merchant, and be laid up in the counter, or Ludgate, so it shall be conscience in you old gentleman, when he hath seized all thy goods, to take the horn and maintain thee.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: O well bold Tom () we have precedents for't.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Well if you be not a nobleman, you are some great valiant gentleman, by your birth: and the fashion of your beard: and do but thus to make the citizen merry, because you owe him some money.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O you are a wag.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: You are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: He is ta'en, excellent, excellent, there's one will make him merry: is it any imputation to help ones friend to a wench?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No more than at my lord's entreaty, to help my lady to a pretty weighting woman: if he had given you a gelding, or the reversion of some monopoly, or a new suit of satin to have done this, happily your satin would have smelled of the pander: but what's done freely, comes like a present to an old lady, without any reward, and what is done without any reward, comes like wounds to a soldier, very honourably notwithstanding.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: This is my breeding gentlewoman: and whether travail you?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: To London sir, as the old tale goes, to seek my fortune.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Shall I be your fortune lady?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O pardon me sir, I'll have some young landed heir to be my fortune, for they favour she fooles more than citizens.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Are you married?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Yes, but my husband is in garrison ith' Low-countries, is his colonel's bawd, and his captain's jester: he sent me word over, that he will thrive: for though is apparel lie ith' Lombard, he keeps his conscience ith' muster-book.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: He may do his country good service lady.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I as many of your captains do, that fight as the geese saved the Capitol, only with prattling: well, well, if I were in some nobleman's hands now, may be he would not take a thousand pounds for me.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: No sir: and yet may be at year's end, would give me a brace of hundreth pounds to marry me to his baily, or the solicitor of his law suits: who's this I beseech you?

div.stage: Enter mistress Maybery her hair loose, with the hostice.

sp.speaker: Hostess.
sp.p: I pray you forsooth be patient.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Passion of my heart, mistress Maybery. Exeunt fiddlers.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Now will she put some notable trick, upon her cuckoldly husband.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Why how now wife, what means this? ha?

sp.speaker: Mi Me.
sp.p: Well, I am very well: o my unfortunate parents, would you had buried me quick, when you linked me to this misery.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O wife be patient, I have more cause to rail wife.

sp.speaker: Misters May.
sp.p: You have, prove it, prove it: where's the courtier, you should have ta'en in my bosom: I'll spit my gall in's face, that can tax me of any dishonour: have I lost the pleasure of mine eyes, the sweets of my youth, the wishes of my blood: and the portion of my friends, to be thus dishonoured, to be reputed vild in London, whilst my husband prepares common diseases for me at Ware, oh god oh god.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p: Prettily well dissembled.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: As I am true hostess you are to blame sir, what are you masters: I'll know what you are afore you depart masters, dost thou leave thy chamber in an honest inn, to come and inveigle my customers, and you had sent for me up, and kissed me and used me like an hostess ▪ 'twould never have grieved me, but to do it to a stranger.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: I'll leave you sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Stay, why how now sweet gentlewoman, cannot I come forth to breathe myself, but I must be haunted, rail upon old Bellamont, that he may discover them, you remember Fetherstone Greenshield.

sp.speaker: Mistress May.
sp.p: I remember them, ay, they are two as cogging, dishonourable damned forsworn beggarly gentlemen, as are in all London, and there's a reverent old gentleman to, your pander in my conscience.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Lady, I will not as the old gods were wont, swear by the infernal Styx: but by all the mingled wine in the seller beneath, and the smoke of tobacco that hath fumed over the vessailes, I did not procure your husband this banqueting dish of sucket look you behold the parenthesis.

sp.speaker: Hostess ▪
sp.p: Nay I'll see your face too.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: My dear unkind husband; I protest to thee I have played this knavish part only to be witty.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: That I might be presently turned into a matter more solid than horn, into marble

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your husband gentlewoman: why he never was a soldier

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I but a lady got him pricked for a captain, I warrant you, he will answer to the name of captain, though he be none: like a lady that will not think scorn to answer to the name of her first husband; though he wear a soap-boiler.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Hang of thou devil, away.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: No, no, you fled me tother day,
when I was with child you ran away,
But since I have caught you now.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: A pox of your wit and your singing.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay look you sir, she must sing because we'll be merry, what though you rod not five mile forward, you have found that fatal house at Brainford northward, oh hone ho no nam ne ro.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: God refuse me gentlemen, you may laugh and be merry: but I am a cuckold and I think you knew of it, who lay ith' sedges with you tonight wild-duck.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: nobody with me, as I shall be saved: but master Fetherstone, came to meet me as far as Roistone.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Fetherstone.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: See the hawk that first stooped, my pheasant is killed by the spaniel that first sprang all of our side wife.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Twas a pretty wit of you sir, to have had him rod into Puckridge with a horn before him; ha: wast not;

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Or where a citizen keeps his house, you know 'tis not as a gentleman keeps his chamber for debt, but as you said even now very wisely, lest his horns should usher him.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Very good Fetherstone he comes. Enter Fetherstone.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Luke Greenshield master Maybery, old poet: Moll and Kate, most happily encountered, udslife how came you heather, by my life the man looks pale.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: You are a villain, and I'll make't good upon you, I am no servingman, to feed upon your reversion.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Go to the ordinary then.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: This is his ordinary fit and in this she is like a London ordinary: her best getting comes by the box.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: You are a damned villain.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: O by no means.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: No, udslife, I'll go instantly take a purse, be apprehended and hanged for't, better than be a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Best first make your confession sirrah.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: 'Tis this thou hast not used me like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: A gentleman: thou a gentleman: thou art a tailor.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ware peaching.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p:
No sirrah if you will confess ought, tell how thou hast
wronged that virtuous gentlewoman: how thou layest at her two year together to make her dishonest: how thou wouldst send me thither with letters, how duly thou wouldst watch the citizens wife's vacation, which is twice a day; namely the exchange time, twelve at noon and six at night, and where she refused thy importunity, and vowed to tell her husband: thou wouldst fall down upon thy knees, and entreat her for the love of heaven, if not to ease thy violent affection, at least to conceal it, to which her pity and simple virtue consented, how thou tookest her wedding ring from her, met these two gentlemen at Ware: feigned a quarrel, and the rest is apparent, this only remains what wrong the poor gentlewoman hath since received by our intolerable lie; I am most heartily sorry for, and to thy bosom will maintain all I have said to be honest.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Victory wise thou art quit by proclamation.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sir you are an honest man, I have known an arrant thief for peaching made an officer, give me your hand sir.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O filthy abominable husband did you all this?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Certainly he is no captain he blushes.

sp.speaker: Mi May.
sp.p: Speak sir did you ever know me answer your wishes.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: You are honest, very virtuously honest.

sp.speaker: Mi May.
sp.p: I will then no longer be a loose woman, I have at my husband's pleasure ta'en upon me this habit of jealousy: I'm sorry for you, virtue glories not in the spoil but in the victory.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.p:
How say you by that goody sentence, look you sir; you gallants visit citizens houses, as the Spaniard first sailed to the Indies, you pretend buying of wares or selling of lands: but the end proves 'tis nothing but for discovery and conquest of their wives for better maintenance why look you, was he aware of those broken patience when you met him at Ware, and possessed him of the downfall of his wife: you are a cuckold you have pandered your own wife to this gentleman better men have done it, honest Tom (), we have presidents for't, hie you to London: what is more catholic ith' city then for husband's daily for to forgive, the nightly sins of their bedfellows: if you like not that course but to intend to be rid of her: rifle her at a tavern, where you may swallow
down some fifty wisacres sons and heirs to old tenements, and common gardens: like so many raw yolks with muskadine to bedward.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: O filthy knave, dost compare a woman of my carriage to a horse.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And no disparagement; for a woman to have a high forehead: a quick ear, a full eye, a wide nostril, a sleek skin, a straight back, a round hip, and so forth is most comely.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But is a great belly comely in a horse sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No lady.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And what think you of it in a woman I pray you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Certainly, I am put down at my own weapon; I therefore recant the riflying? no there is a new trade come up for cast gentlewomen, of periwig making: let your wife set up ith' strand, and yet I doubt, whither she may or no, for they say, the women have got it to be a corporation; if you can you may make good use of it, for you shall have as good a coming in by hair (Though it be but a falling commodity) and by other foolish tiring, as any between saint Clement's and Charing.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Now you have run yourself out of breath, hear me: I protest the gentlewoman is honest, and since I have wronged her reputation in meeting her thus privately, I'll maintain her: wilt thou hang at my purse Kate, like a pair of Barbary buttons, to open when 'tis full, and close when 'tis empty?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I'll be divorced by this Christian element, and because thou thinkst thou art a cuckold, lest I should make thee an infidel, in causing thee to believe an untruth, I'll make thee a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Excellent wench.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Come, let's go sweet: the nag I ride upon bears double, we'll to London.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Do not bite your thumbs sir.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Bite his thumb!
I'll make him do a thing worse than this,
Come love me where as I lay.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: What Kate!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: He shall father a child is none of his,
Oh the clean contrary way.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: O lusty rate. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: methought he said, even now you were a tailor.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: You shall hear more of that hereafter, I'll make ware and him stink ere he goes, if I be a tailor, the rogues naked weapon shall not fright me, I'll beat him and my wife both out ath' town with a tailor's yard. Exit.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: O valiant sir Tristram; room there.

div.stage: Enter Philip Leuer-poole and Chartly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: News father, most strange news out of the Low-countries, your good lady and mistress that set you to work upon a dozen of cheese-trenchers is new lighted at the next inn, and the old venerable gentleman's father with her.

sp.speaker: Bael
sp.p: Let the gates of our inn be locked up, closer than a nobleman's gates at dinner time.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Why sir, why?

sp.speaker: Bella.
sp.p: If she enter here, the house will be infected: the plague is not half so dangerous, as a she-hornet: Philip this is your shuffling a the cards, to turn up her for the bottom card at Ware.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: No as I'm virtuous sir, ask the two gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: No in troth sir; she told us, that enquiring at London for you or your son, your man chalked out her way to Ware.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I would ware might choke 'em both, master Maybery, my horse and I will take our leaves of you? I'll to bedlam again rather than stay her.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Shall a woman make thee fly thy country? stay, stand to her though she were greater than Pope Joan, what are thy brains conjuring for, my poetical bayleaf-eater?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: For a sprite a the buttery, that shall make us all drink with mirth if I can raze it: stay, the chicken is not fully hatched, hit I beseech thee: so; come! will you be secret gentlemen and assisting.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: With brown bills if you think good.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What will you say, if by some trick we put this little hornet into Fetherstone's bosom, and marry 'em together.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Fuh, 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Most possible, I'll to my trencher-woman, let me alone for dealing with her: Fetherstone gentlemen shall be your patient.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: How! how?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thus: I will close with this country pedlar mistress Dorothy (That travels up and down to exchange pins for coney-skins) very lovingly, she shall eat of nothing but sweetmeats in my company (Good words) whose taste when she likes, as I know she will, then will I play upon her with this artillery, that a very proper man, and a great heir (Naming Fetherstone) spied her from a window, when she lighted at her inn, is extremely fallen in love with her, vows to make her his wife, if it stand to her good liking, even in Ware; but being (As most of your young gentlemen are) somewhat bashful, and ashamed to venture upon a woman.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: City and suburbs can justify it: so sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: He sends me (Being an old friend) to undermine for him: I'll so whet the wench's stomach, and make her so hungry, that she shall have an appetite to him, fear it not; Greenshield shall have a hand in it too, and to be revenged of his partner, will I know strike with any weapon.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: But is Fetherstone of any means? else you undo him and her.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: He has land between Foolham and London, he would have made it over to me: to your charge poet, give you the assault upon her, and send but Fetherstone to me, I'll hang him by the gills.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He's not yet horsed sure, Philip, go thy ways, give fire to him, and send him hither with a powder presently.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He's blown up already. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Gentlemen you'll stick to the device, and look to your plot?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Most poetically: away to your quarter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I march, I will cast my rider gallants: I hope you see who shall pay for our voyage. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Phillip and Fetherstone.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: That must he that comes here: master Fetherstone, oh master Fetherstone, you may now make your fortunes weigh ten stone of feathers more than ever they did: leap but into the saddle now, that stands empty for you, you are made for ever.

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: An ass I'll be sworn.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: How for God's sake? how?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p:
I would you had, what I could wish you, I love you, and
because you shall be sure to know where my love dwells, look you sir, it hangs out at this sign: you shall pray for ware, when ware is dead and rotten: look you sir, there is as pretty a little pinnace, struck sail hereby, and come in lately; she's my kinswoman, my father's youngest sister, a ward, her portion three thousand; her hopes if her grannam die without issue, better.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Very good sir.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Her guardian goes about to marry her to a stone-cutter, and rather than she'll be subject to such a fellow, she'll die a martyr, will you have all out? she's run away, is here at an inn ith' town, what parts soever you have played with me, I see good parts in you, and if you now will catch times hair that's put into your hand, you shall clap her up presently.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Is she young? and a pretty wench?

sp.speaker: Lever.
sp.p: Few citizens' wives are like her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Young, why I warrant sixteen hath scarce gone over her.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, where is she? if I like her personage, as well as I like that which you say belongs to her personage, I'll stand thrumming of caps no longer, but board your pinnace whilst 'tis hot.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Away then with these gentlemen with a French gallop, and to her: Philip here shall run for a priest, and dispatch you.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Will you gallants go along: we may be married in a chamber for fear of hue and cry after her, and some of the company shall keep the door.

sp.speaker: May,
sp.p: Assure your soul she will be followed: away therefore. He's in the curtain gulf, and swallowed horse and man: he will have somebody keep the door for him, she'll look to that: I am younger than I was two nights ago, for this physic. — how now?

div.stage: Enter captain. Allom. Hans, and others booted.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: God pless you; is there not an arrant scurvy trab in your company, that is a gentlewoman born sir, and can tawg weleh, and Dutch and any tongue in your head?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: How so? Drabs in my company: do I look like a drab-driver?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The trab will drive you (If she put you before her) into a pench hole.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: Is not a gentleman here one master Bellamont sir of your company.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Yes, yes, come you from London, he'll be here presently.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Will he? tawsone, this oman, hunts at his tail like your little goats in Wales follow their mother, we have warrants here from master sustice of this shire, to show no pity nor mercy to her, her name is doll.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Why sir, what has she committed? I think such a creature is ith' town.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What has she committed: 'ounds she has committed more than manslaughters, for she has committed herself God pless us to everlasting prison: lug you sir, she is a punk, she shifts her lovers (As captains and Welsh gentlemen and such) as she does her trenchers when she has well fed upon't, and that there is left nothing but pale bones, she calls for a clean one, and scrapes away the first.

div.stage: Enter Bellamont, and Hornet, with doll between them Greeneshield, Kate, Maybery's wife, Phillip, Leverpoole, and Chartley.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: God's so master Fetherstone, what will you do? here's three come from London, to fetch away the gentlewoman with a warrant.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: All the warrants in Europe shall not fetch her now, she's mine sure enough: what have you to say to her? she's my wife.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Owe! 'sblood do you come so far to fish and catch frogs? your wife is a tilt-boat, any man or oman may go in her for money; she's a coney-catcher: where is my moveable goods called a coach ▪ and my two wild beasts, pogs on you would they had trawne you to the gallows.

sp.speaker: Allom.
sp.p: I must borrow fifty pound of you mistress Bride.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Yaw uro, and you make me de gheck, de groet fool, you heb mine gelt to: war is it?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Out you base scums, come you to disgrace me in my wedding shoes?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Is this your three thousand pound ward, ye told me sir she was your kinswoman.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Right, one of mine ants.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who pays for the Northern voyage now lads?

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Why do you not ride before my wife to London now? the woodcocks ith' springe.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O forgive me dear husband! I will never love a man that is worse than hanged, as he is.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Now a man may have a course in your park?

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: He may sir.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Never I protest, I will be as true to thee, as ware and wades-mill are one to another.

sp.speaker: Feth.
sp.p: Well, it's but my fate: gentlemen, this is my opinion, it's better to shoot in a bow that has been shot in before, and will never start, than to draw a fair new one, that for every arrow will be warping: come wench we are joined, and all the dogs in France shall not part us: I have some lands, those I'll turn into money, to pay you, and you, and any: I'll pay all that I can for thee, for I'm sure thou hast paid me.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: God give you joy.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Come let's be merry, lie you with your own wife, to be sure she shall not walk in her sleep: a noise of musician's chamberlain.

lg.l: This night let's banquet freely: come, we'll dare,
Our wives to combat ith' great bed in Ware ▪Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
